etymology.description: 刀(刀) (dāo, "knife") + 幺(幺) (yāo, "silk") = to cut silk threads -> ancient form of 絕(絕) (jué, "sever")
etymology.interpretation: Originally, the character 𢇍 depicted the action of cutting silk threads using a knife, emphasizing the precision and sharpness associated with this task. This evolved into the modern character 絕(絕) (jué, "sever"), retaining the idea of separation or cutting.

examples.chinese: 他用锋利的刀𢇍肉(他用鋒利的刀𢇍肉)。
examples.pinyin: Tā yòng fēnglì de dāo qiē ròu.
examples.english: He cuts the meat with a sharp knife.

examples.chinese: 她在厨房里𢇍面条(她在廚房里𢇍麵條)，准备午餐(準備午餐)。
examples.pinyin: Tā zài chúfáng lǐ qiē miàntiáo, zhǔnbèi wǔcān.
examples.english: She cuts noodles in the kitchen while preparing lunch.

examples.chinese: 老匠人在修复文物时(老匠人在修復文物時)，仔细地𢇍破损的绸缎(仔細地𢇍破損的綢緞)。
examples.pinyin: Lǎo jiàngrén zài xiūfù wénwù shí, zǐxì de qiē pò sǔn de chóuduàn.
examples.english: The old craftsman carefully cuts the damaged silk during the restoration of the artifact.
